newsitem.title: UK: Builders launch job-creating budget submission.
newsitem.headline: Builders launch job-creating budget submission.

text.p: The UK's troubled building industry unveiled its 1996 Budget submission on Monday - a blueprint which it said would create more than 100,000 new jobs.

Martin Laing, chairman of John Laing Plc and the Construction Industry Employers' Council, said in a statement "Construction has lost nearly a million jobs since 1990. We are proposing new measures to create jobs, restore confidence and maintain long-term stability." The submission puts forward a five point plan for revitalising the industry.
The industry calls for a new home improvement Tax Exempt Special Savings Account (TESSA) to encourage home-owners to save money for home maintenance.

It also recommends a reduced value added tax (VAT) rate of eight percent (as opposed to the normal 17-1/2 percent rate) for renovation and home alterations. The council estimates this will create 60,000 jobs.

It calls for changes to the Government's private finance initiative, which encourages private sector money into public infrastructure. In particular the industry wants better trained civil servants and less red tape, plus decent sized projects.
It asked for a scrapping of the government's cuts in road maintenance spending and phased release of local authority capital receipts to boost spending on local housing.
Laing summed up "What's good for construction is good for Britain," warning that it was an industry which employed 1.5 million people.
